data.text: Fenders/Mudguards when Long-Distance Cycle Touring?
Question for the experienced. Are fenders worth having? Do the pros outweight the cons?
Depends on how much you will ride in winter rain/ snow
data.author: Tracy Irvin

data.text: Yes‚Ä¶.
data.author: Jeff Pitts

data.text: East coast of the US it rains often, fenders are really nice. I would probably not own them if I lived in the southwest.
data.author: Thomas Wilson

data.text: They are VERY worth it if you ride in the rain. I will go through the trouble of removing them during the dry season because those things frustratingly Ôøºact like parachutes. Ôøº
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: you seem like a great person. However I never want to go parachuting with you! I jokes!
data.author: Katie Dawn Jacobs

data.text: Kona Sutra owner here. I was shortlisting bikes exclusively with fenders, and can‚Äôt imagine not having them. I‚Äôd say depends on the purpose and geography. Im based in London and commute to the office job, so having fenders was a no question for me.
data.author: Michael Goj'an

data.text: Kona Sutra owner as well! I totally agree with Michael here. I took them off for a multi-day trip and put them back on as soon as i got back.
data.author: Jonathan Kulik

data.text: I agree with Michael and Jonathan that the Kona Sutra is the finest touring bike there is, but we part ways on the issue of fenders. I took mine off when I switched from 45s to 55s and I don't miss them. To be fair, most of my miles are on gravel or crushed limestone and not pavement.

data.text: For commuting I can see the benefits, but im prepparimg for Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Germany trip and I'm leanimg towards taking them off. Also l9oking for a better rolling tire. Any suggestions. 90% pavement.

data.text: no advice from me except pedal pedal more pedal

data.text: I took my fenders off my Kona sutra- the rattles and toe hit drove me bonkers I don't care about a little bit of rain

data.text: yeah I got no toe hit on my sultra it‚Äôs big frame 58cm but I like how it rides new wheels will make it perfect I hope

data.text: my bad for being short!
data.author: Melea Lafferty

data.text: i dont hit my toes on my 54 but i suffer from the rattles. Part of the reason im leaning towards pulling them. At least the front. Maybe replace it with a small top mud flap vs fill fender. Keep spray off my face anyways.
data.author: Mark Grunwald

data.text: yep the rattles did my head in
data.author: Melea Lafferty

data.text: Eh! They are nice but when I take my bike on a tour I take them off. The rear seems pointless as I use a large saddle bag that would serve the same purpose.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: No idea about fenders, but wow! That's a beautiful bike!
data.author: Jessica A. Lloyd

data.text: One run through a wet gutter with street clothes on makes that decision.
data.author: Vince Meghrouni

data.text: On my bikes that I would ride much in the rain, I wouldn't be without 'em.
data.author: Jak Conrad

data.text: Rarely rains here, so no. If it does rain we don't ride
data.author: Peter South

data.text: In rainy places such as Iceland, they are priceless, but I don‚Äôt use them here in Alberta.
data.author: Clive Cuttler

data.text: Fenders are necessary unless you believe you will never have to ride in the rain. I think fenderless bikes are kind of ridiculous myself unless they are used solely for fun.
data.author: Marcos Litwikki

data.text: wait, I have fenders and use my bike solely for fun. The ride to work on my bike, fun. Going to the grocery, on the bike, fun. Putting in miles for a summer tour, fun.
data.author: Katie Dawn Jacobs

data.text: For a commuter, yes. For a tourer, probably yes.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: for a tourer definitely yes
data.author: David Brown

data.text: One of my bikes has fenders for wet weather. Don't understand why they are not on every road bike and why some frames make them difficult or impossible to fit.
data.author: Tom Jones

data.text: they aren't fitted to road bikes as standard because they add weight and aero drag. These may not be important to you if you're touring.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: they are not important to anyone other than professional cyclists when racing. If you are riding a bike or driving a car and the only concern you have is how fast can you go, you are a danger to yourself and others. The slowing effect of mudguards is only a factor above 15mph and even then only slight. The great majority of cyclists would never notice any difference. If out to get fit then any drag at speed makes you work a little harder the faster you pedal!
data.author: Tom Jones

data.text: I just cable tie half a long skinny plastic bottle to my rack.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: cheapskate!
data.author: David Brown

data.text: no, I just need something stop water going up my back.
data.author: Paul Hamon
Paul Hamon

data.text: Unless you want wet feet, generally makes it more comfortable in crap conditions
data.author: Johnny Pinkerton

data.text: What are the cons?
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Weight for the light tourer like myself.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: they are awful light
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: They still weigh something. And they‚Äôre essentially pointless. Your rear rack acts as a fender and your front tire barely kicks up any water, even in downpours.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: you do you, but I appreciate mine for sure.
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: For fair weather recreational rides, probably not. But for commuting or touring, when it WILL rain at least some of the time, I say they are essential. But I don't like wet feet and a stripe up my back. üòÑ
data.author: Gary Keese

data.text: I‚Äôve commuted daily over the last 3 years and have fenders mounted. For minimal weight and wind resistance you save yourself getting completely drenched when riding in the rain, as whilst you still get rained on (waterproofs notwithstanding), your bike, clothes, shoes and equipment is saved from the dirty water flicked up from below. I‚Äôm doing a 1500km audax this August and am considering riding even then with fenders just in case.
data.author: Ken Neth

data.text: I use the pdw soda pop removable fenders and they work great especially if you're on the fence about whether you need them full time or not. The rear mounting hardware is a little fragile but can be replaced easily and cheaply. Once you've broken it once or twice you learn how to install and remove without breaking. I'm hesitant to install full time fenders because I ride my bike for commute and recreation and tend to jump, drop, and hop occasionally. For reference, I'm a year round daily commuter with 50+ commute miles per week in coastal California so mild weather and I primarily ride a surly cross check
data.author: Joe Bellagio

data.text: My husband has those but I hate them if I happen to be following him when it‚Äôs wet.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: No. Not worth the extra weight IMO. Your rack will act as a fender and your front tire doesn‚Äôt kick up much water.

data.text: you can't be serious ü§≠

data.text: A must here in the UK .

data.text: Yes!

data.text: Unless you like looking like you pooped yourself in a weirdly straight line after riding in the rain or on wet surfaces, you at least want a back fender.

data.text: If you really aren‚Äôt going to tour and just riding on dry days, not much sense I suppose. But, if you‚Äôre touring you‚Äôll want them to stop that mud and water stripe up your back and into your hair‚Ä¶ My 2¬¢‚Ä¶

data.text: I live in the Northwest and ride to work in the rain all the time without fenders.Ôøº

data.author: David Brown

data.text: Yes and no. I have it on commute bike and are very useful minimalizing backsplash. Also I don't have it on my gravel bike and I'm using ponchos in rain. If you already have it - keep it.
data.author: Tomasz Plasota

data.text: Yes they are necessary
data.author: Maxwell Gosta Chisale

data.text: Depends on the environmental conditions of where you're cycling . . . .
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: Fenders are great for keeping you and your bike (especially its drivetrain) cleaner on a rainy day or riding on wet/muddy surfaces. Cleaning your bike can be more challenging on a multi-week tour. When it‚Äôs really pouring, you will get wet. The only downside I‚Äôve encountered with my full coverage fenders is that I can‚Äôt tip my bike up on its rear wheel to roll it somewhere or fit it into a small elevator. I‚Äôve never had them clog with mud but apparently that‚Äôs possible.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: same problem when rollingnit around from time to time.
data.author: Mark Grunwald

data.text: I had the rear fender clog with clay mud five days ago. Had to dig it out with twigs twice then a dull knife. I wouldn‚Äôt go without fenders though.
data.author: Heather Burles

data.text: Had em when I commuted for 30+ yrs, not so much now I'm retired and ride for fun, even if I get caught in the rain now I am usualy less than an hour or two away from a warm bath.
data.author: Kevin Chessman

data.text: Yes very much so a must im from holland which is like the uk version but the weather changes in a Heartbeat and more rain here so fenders and waterproofs are a must not a option
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Yes, as someone who recently had to cycle over a burst sewer they earned their place on my bike on that tide alone! Its so much nicer knowing that whatever the weather your reasonably well protected from the crud on the road.
data.author: Craig Lindley

data.text: Yes they are just like waterproofs not an option but a must

data.text: glad to have got rid of mine, a nuisance they were on my sutra

data.text: I'm very much in the side of mud guards / fenders for multi day rides or commutes . Aids with the drive chain and personal comfort on a tour

data.text: No mudguards (uk) = wet butt, wet panniers, more water and grit on chain , and filthy legs and bike , you choose ! Why do you think most (real ) touring bikes come fitted with them ü§î
data.author: David Brown

data.text: Yes, and yes. Unless you don't care about squishy wet feet, and a big ol' goopy slime trail from your sitbones to your neck.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: In addition to the fenders, put a front mudflap about 9 inches long made from milk carton plastic hanging from the bottom of the front fender. Attach it with rivets or drill a set of double holes on both left and right sides of the fender and zip tie it on. Really protects your feet and front chainwheel from road spray.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: I put fenders on my treck 720 got stuck On the C&O in Cumberland . Fenders That come off easily Good ideaÔøº
data.author: Fredrick Sullivan

data.text: Fenders anytime! Tried a bunch of other solutions, not good. Just ordered a pair of full fenders. Jan Heines blog has nice articles proving that fenders interfere very little with aerodynamics and bike performance, contrary to what most people think, worth a read.
data.author: Eben√©zer Paz e Silva

data.text: It depends on how fast you ride. I don't have fenders on my touring bike as we normally ride under 20 KMH and have found that I don't have the wheels spinning fast enough to hit me.
data.author: Barry Andrews

data.text: In the summer I ride without on my best bikes but the second it rains or turns to autumn with muddy roads etc, then on to the "winter bike" with full mudguards. Makes a huge difference to ride comfort in that you keep cleaner and generally drier, and keeps most of the damp and crap off you and anything attached the the seatpost (need a long flap on the front guard). Off road in the wet, I use a clip on rear guard to keep the worst off without risking mud clog.
data.author: David Wilson

data.text: I‚Äôd say if you want a fender get one, due you need someone to tell you if you need a fender
data.author: Frank Wilke

data.text: Lovely picture. Good luck on you. Be safe.
data.author: Mikael Ljungberg

data.text: I don't really like the look of mudguards, so I do remove them from my hybrid commuter in the summer. If it rains in the summer (and it does) I have a couple of temporary mudguards from Ass Saver that I attach. The rear one is not really necessary as I have a similar rack to yours - Topeak Super tourer that has a solid plate on the top that acts as a mudguard.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: Depends where you travel and how much it rains.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: Fenders are awesome if you don't like to get your shirts or backpack dirty.
data.author: David Bntz

data.text: It depends how long is your trip. If you‚Äôre planning to go for more than a week I suggest go with a fender. The problem with out a fender is the dirt on the chain, chain ring and on your shoes that goes inside it. I have experienced a burnt ankle because of the sands that goes inside my shoes.
data.author: Ruben Jr Santos

data.text: Always - Big fan of Honjp from Sim Works or Velo Orange fenders
data.author: Vincent Goss

data.text: They drove me nuts on long tour that included wild camping. Over long distance all seasons they often clog with mud, leaves, sticks, snow. Mine went in the bin and now only use for commuting.

data.text: probably not enough clearance by fitting wrong size for the tyres fitted

data.text: Essential, save you, your luggage and your drivetrain. And lots of effort in bike cleaning. SKS Bluemels are excellent I have ones with reflective stripes.

data.text: Commute, then have fenders. For my comfort the fenders are most important I find. I get a lot less water on my glasses, I can see much better.
